title: sin
comment: Primarily a wrong relationship with God, which may express itself in wrong attitudes or actions towards God himself, other human beings, possessions or the environment. Scripture stresses that this condition is deeply rooted in human nature, and that only God is able to break its penalty, power and presence.

children.title: sin, nature of
children.comment: Scripture portrays sin in terms of wrongness before God in a variety of different ways, such as uncleanness, guilt or rebellion.

children.title: All sin is directed against God
Sin is essentially a lack of faith in God
The breaking or transgression of God's laws

primaryrefs.comment: The words most commonly used for ``sin'' in the OT and NT originally signified ``missing the mark''.

children.title: sin, causes of
children.comment: Sin is the result of the fall, at which the creation rebels against God its Creator.

children.title: Sin as a result of the devil's activity
The devil's instigation of the first sin
The devil as the source of sinful behaviour
Sin as a power in the world
Sin's reign from the time of Adam
Sin uses the law to provoke sinful desires
The world is under sin's dominion
Sin is rooted in human nature
The human heart is dominated by sin
Human nature is fundamentally opposed to God
Sin results from giving in to evil desires
Sin results from the human desire to be like God
Sin results when the body is placed at sin's disposal
Sin results from the influence of others
The seriousness of leading others into sin
sin, universality of
children.comment: All human beings sin and are guilty in the sight of God on account of an inherently sinful disposition, which can be traced back to Adam. Acts of sin thus arise from a sinful human heart. The basis of cleansing and cancellation of ``original sin'' is the atoning death of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Adam, the cause of universal sin
The universe is in subjection to sin
Sin is inherent in human nature
Everyone is sinful in God's sight
Some characters in Scripture are described as being blameless in comparison with their contemporaries
sin, effects of
children.comment: Sin affects every level of human existence, including the sinner's relationship with God, with other human beings and with the environment.

children.title: The effects of sin on individuals
Bondage to a continuing habit of sin
The sinful life is equivalent to death
The effects of sin on the sinner before God
The effects of sin on Israel

seealsos.comment: the consequences of sin for Israel

children.title: The effects of sin on the world
sin, and God's character
children.comment: In his righteousness and holiness, God detests sin and its effects upon humanity. In his mercy and grace, he makes available a means of atonement, by the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ.

children.title: God's people are to be holy
God is also merciful and gracious
Jesus Christ is the supreme revelation of God's love for sinners
God's love shown in Jesus Christ's death
The risen Christ gives grace to sinful people
sin, God's judgment on
children.comment: Sin comes under the judgment of God, in that it contradicts his nature and opposes his purposes.

children.title: God is the judge of sin
God's judgment is in proportion to the seriousness of the sin
God's judgment under the Sinaitic covenant

primaryrefs.comment: The Sinaitic covenant makes references to the judgment of future generations for the sins of their parents but, as a principle, this is abolished by later prophets.

children.title: John the Baptist and Jesus Christ warn of judgment
Ways in which God judges sin
God causes sin to bring evil to the sinner
Unrepentant sinners to be expelled from the church
God exercises judgment through a country's legal system
Untimely death is God's judgment on all sin
Sinners are excluded from the kingdom of God
Occasions of God's judgment on sin

secondaryrefs.comment: The Canaanites (the Anakites were earlier inhabitants of Canaan).

children.title: God's final judgment of the world
sin, God's remedy for
children.comment: Under the old covenant, sin was forgiven through sacrifice, prefiguring the atoning death of Jesus Christ, which brings forgiveness of sins under the new covenant.

children.title: Atonement for sins in the OT was through the shedding of blood
Kinds of sin offering in the OT
The sin offering was for unintentional sins
The guilt offering was for unintentional sins, where restitution was required
The annual Day of Atonement cleansed the nation of sin
The priests made atonement on occasions of deliberate national sin

secondaryrefs.comment: Aaron stops the plague after Korah's sin
Phinehas stops the plague after Moab caused Israel to sin.

children.title: Sacrifices of atonement needed to be accompanied by repentance and a willingness to obey
Worshippers recognised the need for repentance and obedience
The prophets declared the need for obedience
The prophets warned of judgment to bring people to repentance
The death of Jesus Christ brings forgiveness for sin
Jesus Christ died on behalf of sinful humanity
The early church proclaimed that Christ died for the sins of others
Jesus Christ bore sin on the cross
Jesus Christ has redeemed people by taking their place
The shedding of Jesus Christ's blood brings forgiveness
sin, God's deliverance from
children.comment: The gospel reveals the purpose and power of God to deal with sin and all of its effects. Scripture uses a range of images to express the comprehensiveness of salvation.

primaryrefs.comment: There is a close relation between ``covering over sin'' and ``atoning for sin''.

children.title: Freedom from sin and the sinful nature
A transition from death to life
sin, accepting forgiveness of
children.comment: Sinners must respond to God's offer of forgiveness through faith in Jesus Christ.

children.title: sin, avoidance of
children.comment: God calls his people to avoid sin, and through Jesus Christ gives them the inner power to be victorious over it.

children.title: God's people are to resist sin
The Christian life is a constant struggle against sin
God helps his people to resist sin
Release from sin through Jesus Christ's death
The avoidance of sin through new life in Jesus Christ
Believers co-operate with Jesus Christ to avoid sin
Believers are to put to death what is sinful in them
Believers are to exchange sinful for righteous behaviour

primaryrefs.comment: The words used here, and in similar passages, are those used for ``taking off'' old clothes and ``putting on'' new ones.

children.title: Believers are to allow the Spirit to inform and direct their conduct
Practical steps for overcoming sin and temptation
The expectation of Jesus Christ's return
A consideration of the consequences of sin
The need to be a good witness to unbelievers
The role of others in avoiding sin
Bad company is to be avoided
A good example is to be followed
Believers are to support one another
